title: USS Cheleb (AK-138)
text:
USS "Cheleb" (AK-138) was a in the service of the <a href="US%20Navy">US Navy</a> in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. It was the only ship of the Navy to have borne this name. It is named after <a href="Beta%20Ophiuchi">Cheleb</a>, a star in the <a href="northern%20hemisphere">northern hemisphere</a> constellation of <a href="Ophiuchus">Ophiuchus</a>.
Construction.
"Cheleb" was laid down 29 December 1943 as <a href="liberty%20ship">liberty ship</a> SS "Lyman J. Gage", MCE hull 520, by <a href="Permanente%20Metals%20Corporation">Permanente Metals Corporation</a>, Yard No. 1, <a href="Richmond%2C%20California">Richmond, California</a>, under a <a href="Maritime%20Commission">Maritime Commission</a> (MARCOM) contract; launched 29 January 1943; sponsored by Mrs. E. E. Carter; and commissioned 1 January 1944, <a href="Lieutenant%20%28navy%29">Lieutenant</a> Addison E. McKimmey, <a href="USNR">USNR</a>, in command.
Service history.
"Cheleb" cleared <a href="San%20Francisco%2C%20California">San Francisco</a> 20 January 1944, for <a href="Pearl%20Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a>, where she loaded ammunition and explosives for transportation to newly won <a href="Kwajalein">Kwajalein</a>, which she reached 19 February. Here her cargo, destined for use in the assault of <a href="Eniwetok">Eniwetok</a> which began that day, was unloaded, and on 11 March, "Cheleb" cleared for <a href="Port%20Hueneme%2C%20California">Port Hueneme, California</a>, base for the Pacific <a href="Naval%20Construction%20Battalions">Naval Construction Battalions</a>. After delivering construction equipment at Pearl Harbor, on 18 April, she returned to <a href="Oakland%2C%20California">Oakland, California</a>, where she was converted to a fleet issue ship.
"Cheleb" loaded a varied cargo at San Francisco, and with it arrived at Kwajalein 5 June 1944, to supply ships readying for the assault on the <a href="Marianas">Marianas</a> 10 days later. "Cheleb" also issued stores at <a href="Majuro">Majuro</a> and Eniwetok until 2 August, when she sailed from the <a href="Marshall%20Islands">Marshalls</a> for San Francisco to reload. Returning to <a href="Ulithi">Ulithi</a> 15 October, she supplied ships of the vast <a href="US%203rd%20Fleet">3rd Fleet</a> for the next month, as they carried out their operations supporting the assault on the <a href="Philippines">Philippines</a>. She returned to the west coast to reload in December, and on 22 January 1945, arrived at Eniwetok to provision ships bound for the invasion of <a href="Iwo%20Jima">Iwo Jima</a>, and later ships destined for the assault on <a href="Okinawa">Okinawa</a>. Another voyage to the west coast for repairs and reloading took place in May and June, and on 22 July, "Cheleb" arrived in <a href="Leyte%20Gulf">Leyte Gulf</a> to take up the task of issuing supplies once more. During this time, she serviced some of the ships conducting the final pounding air attacks on the <a href="Empire%20of%20Japan">Japan</a>ese home islands.
Post-war decommissioning.
"Cheleb" arrived in <a href="Tokyo%20Bay">Tokyo Bay</a> 17 November 1945, and remained to issue provisions and supplies to occupation forces at the ports of <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>, <a href="Yokohama">Yokohama</a>, and <a href="United%20States%20Fleet%20Activities%20Yokosuka">Yokosuka</a>. She returned to San Francisco 12 May, and later sailed to Pearl Harbor, where she was decommissioned 25 July 1946. After use in a special explosives test, she was turned over to the <a href="War%20Shipping%20Administration">War Shipping Administration</a> (WSA) for disposal, her contribution to the Navy's great logistic effort at an end.
The ship was struck from the <a href="Navy%20list">Navy list</a> on 22 May 1947, she was returned to MARCOM the next day, and was placed in the <a href="National%20Defense%20Reserve%20Fleet">National Defense Reserve Fleet</a> at <a href="Suisun%20Bay">Suisun Bay</a>, California.
"Cheleb" was sold for scrapping on 27 March 1978, to <a href="Levin%20Metals%20Corporation">Levin Metals Corporation</a>, for $111,653. She was delivered 19 April 1978.
